VOL. XVII, NO. 29.

VARSITY NINE WINS
FROM ITS OLD RIVAL
Pieper Pitches a Great Game and Defeats Wilson of St. Johns.
GAME MOST EXCITING OF YEAR
Large Attendance Enjoy a Contest Full
of Thrills—Hank Shaw's Double in
the Ninth Puts the Game on Ice.
Pete Porter Next Captain.

In one of the most exciting games
of the year the 'Varsity baseball
team made a fitting windup to its
season last Wednesday by defeating St. John's at Homewood Field.
The game was to have been played
the Saturday preceding, but because

ERNEST PIEPER, '13

Has defeated St. John's for three years—Captain
of this year's nine.
of rain, was postponed. A large
crowd, however, was present and
enjoyed the thrilling contest.
Most of ,the scoring was done ill
the first three innings. At the end
of the third period it stood 3 to 3,
and remained that way until Hank
Shaw lined out a hot one to the left
foul line, driving Webster home
with the winning run.
In the first inning, Noble, the St.
John's catcher, made a home run on
one of the longest hits evfir batted
out at Homewood. In the Hopkins
half, Webster crossed the plate on
a beautiful single to deep right by
Hobbs, making the score i to I.
Bagley got a base on balls in the
second inning, and Dorsey bunted
safely. Captain Pieper hit a hot
one past second base, scoring both
men. He was caught, out, however, trying to reach second.
. St. John's retaliated in the third
when Heise and Wilson got on

A public meeting was held in the
Donovan Room on last Tuesday
afternoon under the auspices of the
Women's Civic League of Baltimore. City Comptroller James F.
Thrift explained to the audience
his duties of office, with special
reference to "The City Markets
and the Control of Weights and
Measures." Comptroller Thrift has
taken great interest in the campaign
of the Civic League against dealers
who use short weights and measures. He advised the. housewives
to have a scale in their own homes,
so that they can tell whether they
are getting proper measure or not.
The lecture was in line with the
last few talks given before the
League, whose purpose it is to get
prominent city officials to explain
to them how to take care of and
beautify the individual homes, as
well as the city at large.

The sophomore lacrosse team defeated the freshman team last Monday afternoon in a very close and
exciting game. The final score was
4 to 3. The sophomores started
the scoring in the first half, when
Lederer put the ball past Primrose
for the first count. The freshmen
evened things up a few minutes
later with a goal by Knipp. Not
long before the end of the half,
Voshell shot another goal for the
sophomores, making the score 2 to
1. The freshmen came back strong
in the second half, Knipp and Evitt
each shooting a goal, and thereby
putting their team in the lead.
About the middle of the half,
Voshell shot his second goal for
the sophomores and thus tied the

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 26, 1913.
The News-Letter Board.

THE N Ews - LETTER Board held
its regular weekly meeting last
Monday afternoon. After the regular routine work was disposed of the
senior membersof the Board,Messrs.
Dickinson, Getz, Rusk,Uhler, Niles,
Marshall and Jacobs, tendered their
resignations. Mr. A. K. Barton
was elected Editor - in - Chief for
next year, while Mr. Hollyday will
continue as Business Manager. The
office of Secretary was abolished,
and a new office of Managing Editor was created. The duties of the
Managing Editor are to collect
copy, read proof and make up the
paper, as well as keep a record of
all rules and resolutions passed by
the Board. Mr. Short was elected
to this office. Messrs. Schaffer,
'14; Spieker, '16; and Peploe, '16,
were elected to membership on the
Board. THF, NEWS - LETTER Will,
therefore, begin its work next year
with a staff of eleven members.
The Board will be entertained this
evening by the retiring editor, Mr.
Dickinson, at his home.
There will be but one more issue
of THE NEWS - LETTER this year.
For fear that this last number may
be filled with accounts of graduating affairs, senior stunts, summer
plans, etc., we are going to take this
opportunity to say a word in praise
of ourselves.
THE NEWS - LETTER has had a
most successful year. Mr. Dickinson, as Editor-in-Chief, has done
much to bring the paper up to its
present high standing. He has been
a most worthy successor of Mr.
Lindsay Rogers and leaves a difficult place for his successor to fill.
Under the able and persevering
efforts of our Business Manager,
the paper has been run economic'ally. We have over eighty advertisers and a larger list of subscribers than we have ever had in
the history of the paper. The edi-

Coming as it did after the remarkable Navy game, this defeat of the
soldier boys ends a very creditable
season. Baseball has always had to
struggle for recognition and support at Hopkins, but from teams

The editor has received the following letter from Coach England:

BALTIMORE, May 22, 1913.
Board of Editors, News-Letter,
Johns Hopkins University.
Gentlemen—In the rush of the
closing days of Johns Hopkins University's 1912-13 year, don't forget
Horrax and Dignan, in the mad
rush "to pat each other on the back."
Not so much publicity as appreciation.
We are proud of our own native
born Hopkins men. There never
were better Hopkins men than Horrax and Dignan—and they came
from other colleges. Horrax has
won more points for Hopkins than
any other Hopkins man. Dignan
has never been beaten in scratch-shot
or discus events in this district.
These gentlemen, likewise, stand
well in their medical classes. They
have never quit, never found fault
with our system of athletic economics, never missed a meet, never
failed to smile in tight places—and
now they leave us.
Surely some one of your editors
can briefly eulogize, not so much
Horrax and Dignan, but the spirit

"Freshies" at the Belvedere.

At the spring meeting of the
American Society of Mechanical
Engineers at the Belvedere, f Dr three
days last week, six freshmen were
employed as clerks. Their work
consisted of registering the 1112111bers, handing out literature, pinning
little buttons on coats, and talking
to the stenographers. Beside4,being
employees, they were guests. They
were able to enjoy the scientific meetings, trip around the harbor, auto
trip through the county, tea at the
Country, Club, trip to Annapolis,
and dance in the Belvedere ballroom.
They .are loud in the praises of the
engineers. The men were Knipp,
Woodward, Poole, Leithjser, Rutledge and Woodward.

One will be awarded to the man
making the longest punt, one to
the man who makes the longest and
most accurate forward pass, and
one to the person who shows the
greatest ability in placement kicking, judged according to both distance and accuracy.
The plan of having a contest of
this sort at the end of the spring
football practice is in vogue at all
of the larger colleges, and its innovation at Hopkins is evidence
of the progressiveness of the management.
Among those who have been out
to the practices and who are going
to compete for the prizes are the
following pigskin chasers: Captain
Raymond Leibensperger, "Buck"
Randall, "Frankie" La Motte,
"Jack" Branham, Frank Hasson,
"Bill" Baker, "Husky" Connelly,
Percy Hall and Myron Bagley.

A man drove up in a buggy to
a suburban hotel. The landlord
came out, and the traveler said to
him: "Sir, disconnect my quadruped from my vehicle, stabulate him
and provide nutritious nourishment,
point out unto me some vacant
chamber within your domicile
where I may partake of quietude
until the auroreal luminance shall
summon me to my ephemeral toil."
The landlord looked in amazement
and then called: "Hey, Jake, come
out. here. Here's a fellow talking
Dutch !"
"How is my client?" inquired the
lawyer at the prison gate.
"Shut up !" replied the warden.

Wednesday's meeting, this amendment was discussed at somelength
both by Graduate Athletic Manager
Harry Burgan and by C. E. Ellicott, the sponsor of the proposed
amendment. The former argued
that the harmony at present existing between the Board and the
various managers would certainly

themselves becoming members of

on the other hand, that practical
co-operation between the Board and

conditions, certainly impossible;
and that the only thing to remedy
this was the presence of the undergraduate manager on the Board
as a member. A constitutional
amendment requires, however, a
two-thirds vote to pass; the voting
on this amendment was seventytwo for, and fifty-three against.
The amendment, therefore, was
voted down.
Undergraduate Examinations.

Undergraduate instruction will be
completed by Wednesday evening,
May 28. Thursday, the 29th, will
be a University holiday, to allow
industrious students to "cram" for
the examinations. These latter begin on Friday, May 30, and continue until Thursday, June 5. We
think that this space is more important that the exams, and we will,
therefore, refrain from publishing
the schedule. All interested persons can consult the bulletin board.
THE NEWS-LETTER takes this opportunity to urge everyone to work
hard especially for the latter exams,
so that there will be no pangs of
remorse or regret to mar the senior
prom and the trip "down the bay."

A public meeting was held in the
Donovan Room on last Tuesday
afternoon under the auspices of the
Women's Civic League of Baltimore. City Comptroller James F.
Thrift explained to the audience
his duties of office, with special
reference to "The City Markets
and the Control of Weights and
Measures." Comptroller Thrift has
taken great interest in the campaign
of the Civic League against dealers
who use short weights and measures. He advised the. housewives
to have a scale in their own homes,
so that they can tell whether they
are getting proper measure or not.
The lecture was in line with the
last few talks given before the
League, whose purpose it is to get
prominent city officials to explain
to them how to take care of and
beautify the individual homes, as
well as the city at large.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 26, 1913.
The News-Letter Board.

THE N Ews - LETTER Board held
its regular weekly meeting last
Monday afternoon. After the regular routine work was disposed of the
senior membersof the Board,Messrs.
Dickinson, Getz, Rusk,Uhler, Niles,
Marshall and Jacobs, tendered their
resignations. Mr. A. K. Barton
was elected Editor - in - Chief for
next year, while Mr. Hollyday will
continue as Business Manager. The
office of Secretary was abolished,
and a new office of Managing Editor was created. The duties of the
Managing Editor are to collect
copy, read proof and make up the
paper, as well as keep a record of
all rules and resolutions passed by
the Board. Mr. Short was elected
to this office. Messrs. Schaffer,
'14; Spieker, '16; and Peploe, '16,
were elected to membership on the
Board. THF, NEWS - LETTER Will,
therefore, begin its work next year
with a staff of eleven members.
The Board will be entertained this
evening by the retiring editor, Mr.
Dickinson, at his home.
There will be but one more issue
of THE NEWS - LETTER this year.
For fear that this last number may
be filled with accounts of graduating affairs, senior stunts, summer
plans, etc., we are going to take this
opportunity to say a word in praise
of ourselves.

The editor has received the following letter from Coach England:

BALTIMORE, May 22, 1913.
Board of Editors, News-Letter,
Johns Hopkins University.
Gentlemen—In the rush of the
closing days of Johns Hopkins University's 1912-13 year, don't forget
Horrax and Dignan, in the mad
rush "to pat each other on the back."
Not so much publicity as appreciation.
We are proud of our own native
born Hopkins men. There never
were better Hopkins men than Horrax and Dignan—and they came
from other colleges. Horrax has
won more points for Hopkins than
any other Hopkins man. Dignan
has never been beaten in scratch-shot
or discus events in this district.
These gentlemen, likewise, stand
well in their medical classes. They
have never quit, never found fault
with our system of athletic economics, never missed a meet, never
failed to smile in tight places—and
now they leave us.
Surely some one of your editors
can briefly eulogize, not so much
Horrax and Dignan, but the spirit

"Freshies" at the Belvedere.

At the spring meeting of the
American Society of Mechanical
Engineers at the Belvedere, f Dr three
days last week, six freshmen were
employed as clerks. Their work
consisted of registering the 1112111bers, handing out literature, pinning
little buttons on coats, and talking
to the stenographers. Beside4,being
employees, they were guests. They
were able to enjoy the scientific meetings, trip around the harbor, auto
trip through the county, tea at the
Country, Club, trip to Annapolis,
and dance in the Belvedere ballroom.
They .are loud in the praises of the
engineers. The men were Knipp,
Woodward, Poole, Leithjser, Rutledge and Woodward.

One will be awarded to the man
making the longest punt, one to
the man who makes the longest and
most accurate forward pass, and
one to the person who shows the
greatest ability in placement kicking, judged according to both distance and accuracy.
The plan of having a contest of
this sort at the end of the spring
football practice is in vogue at all
of the larger colleges, and its innovation at Hopkins is evidence
of the progressiveness of the management.
Among those who have been out
to the practices and who are going
to compete for the prizes are the
following pigskin chasers: Captain
Raymond Leibensperger, "Buck"
Randall, "Frankie" La Motte,
"Jack" Branham, Frank Hasson,
"Bill" Baker, "Husky" Connelly,
Percy Hall and Myron Bagley.

A man drove up in a buggy to
a suburban hotel. The landlord
came out, and the traveler said to
him: "Sir, disconnect my quadruped from my vehicle, stabulate him
and provide nutritious nourishment,
point out unto me some vacant
chamber within your domicile
where I may partake of quietude
until the auroreal luminance shall
summon me to my ephemeral toil."
The landlord looked in amazement
and then called: "Hey, Jake, come
out. here. Here's a fellow talking
Dutch !"
"How is my client?" inquired the
lawyer at the prison gate.
"Shut up !" replied the warden.

Wednesday's meeting, this amendment was discussed at somelength
both by Graduate Athletic Manager
Harry Burgan and by C. E. Ellicott, the sponsor of the proposed
amendment. The former argued
that the harmony at present existing between the Board and the
various managers would certainly
be disturbed upon the managers
themselves becoming members of
the Board. The latter contended,
on the other hand, that practical
co-operation between the Board and
a manager, was, under the present
conditions, certainly impossible;
and that the only thing to remedy
this was the presence of the undergraduate manager on the Board
as a member. A constitutional
amendment requires, however, a
two-thirds vote to pass; the voting
on this amendment was seventytwo for, and fifty-three against.
The amendment, therefore, was
voted down.
Undergraduate Examinations.

Undergraduate instruction will be
completed by Wednesday evening,
May 28. Thursday, the 29th, will
be a University holiday, to allow
industrious students to "cram" for
the examinations. These latter begin on Friday, May 30, and continue until Thursday, June 5. We
think that this space is more important that the exams, and we will,
therefore, refrain from publishing
the schedule. All interested persons can consult the bulletin board.
THE NEWS-LETTER takes this opportunity to urge everyone to work
hard especially for the latter exams,
so that there will be no pangs of
remorse or regret to mar the senior
prom and the trip "down the bay."
